title: Isolation of slow-cycling cancer cells from lung patient-derived xenograft using carboxyfluorescein-succinimidyl ester retention-mediated cell sorting
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Establishment of lung PDX mouse model
Timing: 4–8 weeks
In this section, we describe the establishment of the lung PDX model with NOD/SCID mice.
Note: Stock of PDX sample should be stored in a liquid nitrogen tank with screw cap cryogenic tube. Do not repeat the freeze-thaw cycle to keep the viability of the sample.
Note: Unless specified instructions, it is strongly recommended to perform the process below in sterile conditions to prevent possible contamination.
Take a frozen lung PDX sample out from a liquid nitrogen storage tank.
Note: There is a possibility for murine-cell infiltration and contamination while tumor grows in mice. It is recommended to begin with fresh PDX samples without necrotic regions and murine stromal cell infiltration.
Resuscitate the frozen lung PDX sample by incubating it in a 37°C water bath for 1 min.
In a biological safety cabinet (BSC), place a 60 mm culture dish on ice. Bring the thawed lung PDX sample to the culture dish with 5 mL of complete culture media [RPMI 1640 with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) and 1% penicillin-streptomycin solution] to prevent the sample from drying.
Mince the PDX sample into 2–3 mm3 pieces with a sterile surgical scalpel and keep it aside on ice.
Prepare anesthesia cocktail solution by mixing ketamine/xylazine/PBS.
Note: The usage doses of the anesthesia cocktail are ketamine 200 mg/kg and xylazine 10 mg/kg.
Anesthetize 6–8-week-old female NOD/SCID mouse by injecting the anesthesia cocktail 100 μL per 10 g of body weight.
Note: The anesthesia onset takes 3–5 min with 30–40 min duration.
Remove the hair of the right flank of NOD/SCID mouse with clippers.
Make a 10–15 mm skin incision on the shaved region with surgical scissors.
Secure enough space under the skin by pushing a trocar needle.

Load 3–5 pieces of PDX samples on the tip of stainless-steel trocar needle. Add 20 μL of Matrigel over the loaded tissues and inject subcutaneously into the NOD/SCID mice.
Note: Matrigel helps to improve the frequency of tumor formation.
Close the surgical region with a sterile suture.
Return the mouse to the cage and monitor the mouse until fully recovered.
Note: Maintain the PDX-implanted mouse in a specific pathogen-free (SPF) room at a stable temperature (22 ± 2°C) with ad libitum availability of standard chow and water and 12 h of light/dark cycle.
Remove the suture by 10–14 days after surgical intervention.
Observe the PDX tumor growth and wait until it reaches the appropriate size (<500 mm3).
Note: The time to reach the endpoint can vary depending on the condition of the PDX sample, the initial amount of tissue implanted, and/or the condition of the mouse.
Collection of lung PDX tumor from immunodeficient mouse and establishment of a primary cell line
Timing: 2 h
In this section, we describe the processes of harvest and dissociation of PDX tumor for obtaining a primary cell line.
Anesthetize the PDX-bearing mouse by injecting an anesthesia cocktail of 100 μL per 10 g of body weight.
Shave around the PDX tumor with clippers and disinfect the surgery area with a 70% ethanol cotton swipe.
Dissect the flank skin and detach the PDX tumor.
Critical: It is strongly recommended to perform this procedure in a BSC with sterile surgical tools and materials to prevent possible contamination.
Critical: Remove the mouse dermis and necrotic parts completely from the tumor. It is important to secure viable tumor cells and to increase the yield of PDX primary cells.
Note: Surgical tools can be sterilized by autoclave sealed with an instant sealing sterilization pouch.

Place the collected PDX tumor in5 mL of complete culture media in a 15 mL conical tube for temporary storage or transport. Keep the sample in ice (4°C).
Note: Cutting into smaller pieces in this step may help to keep the sample submerged in the culture media preventing it from drying out.
In BSC, place the PDX tumor in a 60 mm culture dish on ice with 5 mL of complete culture media. Mince the PDX tumor into several small pieces of ∼2–4 mm with a sterile scalpel.
Note: Chopping the PDX tumor into smaller pieces increases the efficacy of tumor dissociation enzymes and the yield of single cells.
Prepare the human Tumor Dissociation Kit (Miltenyi Biotec) component enzymes (Enzymes H, R, and A) by adding culture media (RPMI 1640) according to the manufacturer’s instructions (Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]). For storage, prepare aliquots of the enzyme solutions with proper volume to avoid repeated freeze-thaw cycles.

Transfer the chopped PDX tumor into a gentleMACS™ C tube and add 2.2 mL of RPMI 1640 media, 100 μL of Enzyme H, 50 μL of Enzyme R, and 12.5 μL of Enzyme A.
Attach the C tube to the gentleMACS™ dissociator and run program h_tumor_01.
Detach the C tube and incubate in a 37°C CO2 incubator for 30 min while inverting C tube every 5 min.

Attach the C tube to the gentleMACS™ dissociator and run program h_tumor_02 (1st round) (Tables 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2] and 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3]).

Note: Depending on the PDX tumor type, select the appropriate program. The classification is based on the histological composition of the tissue.
Detach the C tube and Incubate in a 37°C CO2 incubator for 30 min while inverting C tube every 5 min.
Attach the C tube to the gentleMACS™ dissociator and run program h_tumor_02 (2nd round).
Note: Run the appropriate gentleMACS program according to the Table 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl4].
Detach the C tube and centrifuge at 300 × g for 1 min at room temperate (RT, 22 ± 2°C) to collect the dissociated cells.
Resuspend the dissociated cell pellet with 10 mL of culture media (complete RPMI 1640) and transfer the cell suspension into a cell strainer (70 μm) placed on a 50 mL conical tube. Add 10 mL of culture media (complete RPMI 1640) to wash cells through the strainer.
Centrifuge the filtered cell suspension at 300 × g for 7 min. Remove the supernatant completely and resuspend the cell pellet in 5 mL of cell culture media (complete RPMI 1640).
Note: (optional) If the cell suspension is viscous, add DNase at 200 U/mL and incubate for 5 min at RT.
Add 100 μL of 0.4% trypan blue solution to 100 μL cell suspension.
Load 10 μL of cell suspension on a hemocytometer and count a viable (unstained) cell number.
Seed 0.5–1 × 107 viable cells per a 90 mm culture dish with 10 mL complete culture media. Incubate cells at 37°C in a 5% CO2 incubator for -12–24 h.
Note: If you want to establish a primary PDX cell line, maintain these dissociated cells with subculture every 4–5 days.
[troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3]].
CFSE staining
Timing: 60 min

In this section, we describe the process of CFSE staining for distinguishing SCCs.
Remove unattached dead cells and floating murine-immune cells with 5 mL of PBS (for a 90 mm culture dish) twice.
Add 1 mL of 2× TE solution to detach the viable cells from the culture dish. Incubate the cells in 37°C CO2 incubator for 5 min.
Note: Sometimes the primary culture cells are more firmly attached to the bottom of the cell plate. As such, increase the incubation time with TE buffer up to 10 min.
Add complete culture media of two times the volume of 2× TE solution. Transfer the detached cells to a 15 mL conical tube and centrifuge at 300 × g for 7 min at RT.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend and wash the cell pellet with 5 mL PBS. Centrifuge at 300 × g for 7 min at RT.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the cells at 2–20 × 107 cells/mL in sterile PBS.
Note: It is recommended for a researcher to determine how many cells will be stained depending on the purpose of downstream analyses.
Note: Take 1 × 105 cells and seed them in a 90 mm culture dish for CFSE unstained control cells.
Prepare 5 mM CFSE stock solution by adding 36 μL of anhydrous DMSO to 100 μg of lyophilized CFSE.
Note: Please refer to the manufacturer’s protocol.
CFSE Cell Division Tracker Kit (d1spbj2x7qk4bg.cloudfront.net)[href=https://d1spbj2x7qk4bg.cloudfront.net/en-gb/products/cfse-cell-division-tracker-kit-9396?pdf=true&displayInline=true&leftRightMargin=15&topBottomMargin=15&filename=CFSE%20Cell%20Division%20Tracker%20Kit.pdf&v=20230114013553].
Prepare 2× concentration of CFSE working solution (10–200 μM) by diluting the stock solution in the same volume of PBS for cell resuspension.
Mix well the cell suspension with 2× CFSE working solution to stain the cells.
Incubate the cells at 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator for 20 min. Tap the staining tube every 5 min for mixing (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).

Figure 1. CFSE staining with increasing concentration
Photograph of the cells with 0, 5, 10, 25, 50, and 100 μM CFSE staining at 37°C for 20 min.
Note: Keep the cells protected from light.
Critical: High concentration of CFSE is toxic for cells. Determine the ideal CFSE staining concentration based on the cell number and growth rate compared to the unstained control.
Quench the CFSE staining by adding 10% FBS-containing complete culture media holding at least 5 times the staining volume.
Centrifuge at 300 × g for 7 min. Remove the supernatant completely and resuspend the cells with fresh complete media.
Seed 1–5 × 105 cells per a 90 mm culture dish for up to 5 days (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).

Cell sorting
Timing: 2 h
In this section, we describe the process of flow cytometry cell sorting to obtain human cancer cells and the isolation of cancer cell subpopulations depending on their proliferation rates.

Detach the stained cells with 1 mL of 2× TE buffer. Incubate the cells in 37°C CO2 incubator for 5 min. After adding 2 mL of complete culture media collect the detached cells in a 15 mL conical tube.
Centrifuge at 300 × g for 7 min.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the cell pellet with 5 mL PBS for washing.
Centrifuge at 300 × g for 7 min.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet with 3 mL PBS.
Load 10 μL of cell suspension on hemocytometer for cell counting.
Take a desirable number of CFSE-stained cells and transfer them to a new sterile 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube.
Note: Decide the cell number for following cell sorting based on how many cells the researcher requires for downstream experiments.
Note: In this protocol, the final CFSEhigh or CFSElow populations would be about 5% of total cell number.
Note: Transfer 1–5 × 105 cells into a new 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube a APC FMO control (CFSE-stained only).
Centrifuge at 300 × g for 7 min.
Remove the supernatant.
Resuspend the cell pellet with sterile flow cytometry buffer at 106 cells/100 μL.
Note: Flow cytometry buffer (0.5% BSA, 2 mM EDTA in PBS) should be sterilized by filtration (0.22 μm).
Note: For the unstained control cells, resuspend the cells with the same volume of staining tube.
Stain the cells with murine CD45-APC, CD31-APC, and PDGFRα-APC antibodies (1:200, v/v) at 4°C for 30 min.
Note: Keep the cells protected from light.
Add 1 mL flow cytometry buffer and centrifuge at 300 × g for 7 min at 4°C.
Remove the supernatant and wash the cell pellet with 1 mL flow cytometry buffer.
Centrifuge at 300 × g for 7 min.

Remove the supernatant and wash the cell pellet with 1 mL flow cytometry buffer one more time.
Centrifuge at 300 × g for 7 min.
Remove the supernatant completely. Resuspend the cell pellet with flow cytometry buffer at 1–4 × 106 cells/mL concentration.
Critical: Cell concentration is important to achieve efficient cell separation. The recommended cell concentration is 0.5–1 × 106 cells in 250–1,000 μL flow cytometry buffer.
Transfer the resuspended cells into the FACS tube strainer cap.
Note: FACS tubes and their strainer caps should be sterile to avoid contamination. Always perform this procedure on a BSC.
Sort the cells with the FACS Aria cell sorter III (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).

Figure 3. Gating strategy for sorting of CFSElow, CFSEmid, and CFSEhigh populations from primary culture cells.
Draw a gate for live cell populations (y-axis: SSC-A, x-axis: FSC-A).
Draw a linear gate for a single cell population (y-axis: FSC-H, x-axis: FSC-A).
Select APC-negative cell populations, which represent human tumor cells (APC-positive cells represent murine immune cells, endothelial cells, and stromal cells; y-axis: SSC-A, x-axis: APC-A).
Note: Draw an APC-negative gate based on APC FMO control (CFSE-stained only).
[troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9]].
Divide the cell populations into three regions: FITC high, FITC middle, and FITC low. Each population represents cancer cells with low, middle, and high proliferation rates (y-axis: SSC-A, x-axis: FITC-A).
Note: Draw a bottom line of CFSEmid upper than CFSE unstained.
Note: We expect to obtain the sorted populations up to 50% of viability.
Note: The recommended threshold for determining CFSElow, CFSEmid, and CFSEhigh are bottom 10%, middle 30%–40%, and upper 10% of APC-negative population.
[troubleshooting 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.11]].
Prepare sterile 15 mL conical tubes as collection reservoirs with 6 mL complete cell culture media.

Note: To increase the yield of sorted cells, wet the walls of the collection tube with cell culture media before sorting.
Collect the sorted cells in sterile collection tubes.
Centrifuge the sorted cells at 300 × g for 7 min.
Remove the supernatant.
Resuspend the sorted cells with 5 mL of fresh culture media.
Centrifuge at 300 × g for 7 min.
Resuspend the cells with 3–5 mL of culture media depending on the cell pellet size.
Cell proliferation assay
Timing: 4–5 days
In this section, we describe an assay to evaluate the proliferation rates of CFSE-sorted cells.
Seed 200 cells of CFSEhigh, CFSEmid, and CFSElow in 12 well plates (200 cell/1 mL culture media).
[troubleshooting 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.13]].
Incubate 12 well plate in a 37°C 5% CO2 incubator for 4 days.
Aspirate cell culture media and wash cells with 1 mL PBS.
Remove PBS and wash cells with 1 mL PBS one more time.
Remove PBS completely.
Fix the cells with 100% methanol for 10 min at RT.
Aspirate the methanol from the well.
Stain cells with 0.5% crystal violet solution for 1 h at RT.
Remove the staining solution.
Wash remained staining solution with 3 mL of distilled water three times.
Analyze stained CFSElow, CFSEmid, and CFSEhigh cells.
Note: Refer to the Cho et al., 2021 (Ref. #1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]) publication for more in vitro and in vivo experiments comparing cellular properties among CFSElow, CFSEmid, and CFSEhigh.
